description: The three remaining great pillars in the chapel take up an entire square each and provide cover (+4 to AC, +2 on Reflex saves) to anyone standing behind them.
name: Massive Pillars

description: The pillar in the southwest portion of the room has been shattered, creating an area of dense rubble that hampers movement across five squares. It costs 2 squares of movement to enter these rubble-strewn squares. The DC of Balance and Tumble checks increases by 5, and the DC of Move Silently checks increases by 2 while char- acters are standing in or moving through these squares. Any character touching the altar
name: Shattered Pillar

description: The secret door connects area K25 to area K13. A DC 25 Search check is needed to find the secret door. Even though the door is well hidden, there are tiny cracks around it that Strahd can use to escape the room in gaseous form. If a PC has seen Strahd escape through these cracks, that character gains a +4 circumstance bonus on Search checks to find and open the door.
name: Secret Door

description: A large window in the west wall consists of many small panes of thick, opaque glass. Several of the panes have been broken, letting in the cold night air. A chill wind blows through the room, swirling a scattering of dead leaves from the outside.
name: Window

name: Stairs

description: 1d20+11. Lief uses his Charisma modifi er instead of his Wisdom modifi er for this check.
name: To resist Intimidate

description: Hostile.
name: Starting Attitude

description: Apply the following modifi ers to any Diplomacy check made to infl uence Lief’s attitude, based on the PCs’ manner and specifi c things they mention in their interaction with him. All of these bonuses stack with each other. • PCs try to talk about accounting or fi nances (–1); • PCs are fawning or fl attering (–2); • PCs are authoritative and demanding (+1); • PCs imply that Lief is a captive (–1); • PCs make any reference to the deathlocks (–1) • The PCs offer Lief an alcoholic beverage (+2)
name: Modifi ers

description: This large, low table is heaped with rolls of parch- ment and heavy tomes. A Medium character can step onto it (or a Small character can jump onto it with a DC 10 Jump check), but it counts as difficult terrain (it costs 2 squares of movement to enter).
name: Table

description: Tall bookshelves line the walls. They do not hamper movement, and they are bolted to the wall so they cannot be tipped over.
name: Shelves

description: The door in the west wall leads to the Audience Hall (K25). The door in the east wall leads to the South Tower Stairs (K21).
name: Doors

description: The tables are stacked with an array of materials, most of them not particularly valuable. A careful examination (DC 18 Search check) of the tables in K55 uncovers 1 vial of acid, two flasks of alchemist fire, 100 tindertwigs, 3 vials of antitoxin, 2 sunrods, 1 tanglefoot bag, 3 thunderstones, 10 vials of ipecac (see page 209), and a glass jar with a single live garden larva sealed inside it (see page 157). One jar holds a dead shocker lizard, while another contains 18 shocker lizard FIRST VIEW eggs, half of which are viable (each worth about 10 gp).
name: Tables

description: A silver key is visible at the bottom of this cauldron.
name: Cauldron

description: This parapet rises high above the castle—only two towers rear higher. Bluish sludge covers the parapet, secreted by nearly a dozen white, wet, rat- sized slugs. The slugs move slowly, migrating among pooled sludge and vaguely anthropoid fl eshly bulbs rooted into the stone parapet. The parapet is ever so slightly canted, enough so that the excess sludge languidly drains along the northern catwalk into an entrance on the neighboring tower. An acidic, vinegar-like odor dominates the air.
name: When PCs fi rst look upon this area, read

description: Excess effluvia from garden larva form two retreats here after fi ghting the PCs to warn the devil about pools of bluish goo in low spots on the parapet. Each pool is the intruders), use the tactical statistics found on page 154. about three feet deep at the center, completely transparent,
name: Ichor Pools

description: This human’s body is gaunt and pale. Its once-fi ne clothes are tattered, and a pair of vicious canines dominates its dark red mouth.
name: Vampire Spawn

description: The landing is slick with bluish goo that slowly oozes in from K57. Any humanoid that fights within 5 feet of the goo-slicked edge of the shaft must make a DC 15 Balance check each round or fall 190 feet (19d6 damage) to the tower floor (K20).
name: Tower Shaft

description: Each step up and down from the landing ascends or descends two feet. Each step if 5 feet wide. No railing guards against accidental fall into the tower shaft.
name: Stairs

description: This human’s body is gaunt and pale. Its once-fi ne clothes are tattered, and a pair of vicious canines dominates its dark red mouth. Use the statistics found on page 158.
name: Vampire Spawn

description: Each step down from the landing descends 2 feet. Each step if 5 feet wide. No railing guards against falls into the tower shaft.
name: Stairs

description: CR 7; mechanical; location trigger; auto- tures 5 feet to the west and onto the chute trap (Reflex DC 17 matic reset; Refl ex DC 25 avoids; chute channels victims to avoid). The rejuvenating form of Rafail might also be here, outside tower 260 feet above northeast quadrant of courtyard depending on PCs’ earlier actions. (20d6, fall); Search DC 27 to fi nd; Disable Device DC 18 to
name: Chute Trap

description: A giant worker ant and a giant soldier ant mill about the stalker’s den. Giant ants look like regular ants, except for their extraordinary size. TACTICS The troll stalker emerges from the K21 stairwell and attempts to attack the PC who most looks like a warrior. Being invisible, the troll stalker gains a +2 bonus on attack rolls against sighted opponents, and ignores its opponents’ Dexterity bonus to AC (if any). The stalker’s position cannot be pinpointed by visual means. It has concealment; even if the square where it is located is correctly guessed, the attacker has a 50% miss chance in combat. 163 EENNCCOOUUNNTTEERR KK6611 9955339933772200__CChh0044__EEnncc..iinndddd 116633 77//2266//0066 77::5522::5566 PPMM W C IINNEE EELLLLAARR Encounter Level 9 Use this encounter with the room entry on page 110. This encounter takes place when the player characters attempt to enter this area. If the PCs attempt to open the portcullis by bending the bars or lifting the gate, they set off the pit trap in the fl oor of room K62. All those who succumb to the trap fall diagonally into a concealed pit in room K63. A wraith (marked as W on the map) haunts the concealed pit, attacking all that fall into the pit. When the trap is triggered, or when the room is entered, combat rounds begin. A construct of broken wine-bottle shards (a glass shrapnyl, S on the map) assembles on its turn in the initiative order. It attacks those PCs not in the pit. Another wraith (W) haunts the K18 stairwell. It moves through a crack in the wall on the second full round of actions to attack the nearest PC. A spiderlike vermin called a chelicera (C) hides in the southern corner of the room. It begins to use its mimicry ability to attract one or more PCs. FIRST VIEW
name: Giant Ants

description: The fl oor in front of the portcullis drops away, sending all those standing on it tumbling down a dark, diagonal shaft. PIT TRAP The fl oor to the west of the portcullis (a 10-foot by 40-foot section) is really a trap door. When the PCs attempt to open the portcullis, the trap door swings down and drops any PCs standing on it diagonally into a 10-foot-by-40-foot pit on the other side of the portcullis. The pit is 20 feet deep. It is open to the room above, but until the trap is triggered it is concealed by a minor glamer (CL 5th; illusion) that makes the area appear to be solid fl oor. A wraith hides within the pit, waiting for anyone to fall in. Broken bottles, bones, and other useless trash litter the fl oor of the pit. The portcullis can’t be opened in any way, but it doesn’t descend lower than the level of the fl oor. Characters can enter the pit and climb out the other end to get into area K63.
name: When the pit trap is triggered, read

description: These massive, heavy racks each store a hun- dred or more wine bottles. Most of the contents have turned to vinegar.
name: Wine Racks

description: This construct is composed of whirling, airborne shattered wine bottles. Razor sharp shards spin and whirl in a Large vortex, obviously dangerous once active. When quiet, the shrapnyl appears as a layer of broken glass on the ground.
name: Glass Shrapnyl

description: This corpse appears to be a zombie until it makes a successful attack. Then its long, clawed tongue becomes obvious.
name: Mohrg

description: There are two monstrous spiders (S) hiding in the alcoves. These aggressive predators use their poisonous bites to subdue and kill prey.
name: Monstrous Spider

description: A wraith appears as a fl oating spectral fi gure robed in darkness. It has the barest shape of a humanoid, but the only distinguishing feature is its glowing red eyes.
name: Wraith

description: This towering, bloated giant looks depends on how they approach it. as if its skin is about to burst. Thick veins fork across its If the PCs enter this area from one of the stairs in the fl esh, and its body pulses and shifts as if a great quantity northern part of the room, the sanctum initially contains of fl uid strains beneath its skin. two bloodhulk giants (marked as B on the map) and a
name: Bloodhulk Giant

description: CR 7; mechani- Strahd Zombies (2) CR 2 cal; action trigger (attempting to open or unlock Crypt 6, or failing to open Crypt 6 or disarm the trap); manual HP 40 each _____________________________________________ reset; Atk +18 ranged (1d4+1 plus poison, dart); poison NE Medium undead (humanoid) Init +0; Senses darkvision 60 ft.; Listen +0, Spot +0 (greenblood oil, Fortitude DC 13 resists, 1 Con/1d2 Con); multiple targets (1d8 darts per target in a 10-ft.-by-10-ft. area AC 16, touch 10, flat-footed 16 as shown); Search DC 25 to fi nd; Disable Device DC 25 to HD 6 Immune mind-affecting, poison, sleep, paralysis, stunning, disengage the trap. disease, death effects, critical hits, nonlethal damage, ability drain, energy drain TACTICS Fort +2, Ref +2, Will +5
name: Fusillade of Greenblood Oil Darts

description: The spectre Endorovich appears as an incorpo- real man in dark clothes, with long dark hair, and a haunted expression. His form is luminous and ghostly, and he fl oats more than walks through any encounter. A feeling of death and dread hangs around the spectre like a cloud of fl ies. T M D ACTICAL AP ETAILS Details on the tactical map are described below.
name: Spectre

description: A heavy stone door (Strength DC 20 to open) seals each crypt. Most crypts have epitaphs inscribed on their doors. Crypt 7 Door: The door of this crypt is off its iron hinges and lies upon the fog-swirled catacomb floor.
name: Crypts

description: VAULT If PCs enter this vault by way of the shaft from Crypt 14, read the following aloud when they reach the bottom: This dank, dripping vault is awkwardly shaped, low, and smells of rotted meat. A dozen or more stone coffi ns cover the fl oor of the vault, each neatly, somehow ominously, arranged so that the top of each coffi n faces north. When a PC opens a coffi n and reveals one of the undead resting here, combat rounds begin.
name: FIRST VIEW

description: A COLD, DARK PLACE If a PC is transported into a coffi n due to the trap in K86, randomly place that PC in any coffi n with a wight. The wight appears in the PC’s place in K86 and immediately attacks the rest of the party. The sudden arrival of life in the chamber causes the undead to arise and swarm. The wights become active as described above (1d4+1 per round until all thirteen are active), moving toward the PC’s coffi n to attack and feast on the unfortunate victim. The shadow and the wraith behave as described above, targeting the newly arrived PC.
name: TACTICS

description: The statues appear to be regal marble figures of Rock Throwing (Ex) The range increment is 180 feet for a stone giant’s thrown rocks. It uses both hands when kings of old, each standing about 10-feet tall. If the PCs throwing a rock. There are no rocks to throw here in the make a concerted effort to examine the statues more closely, tomb, and it won’t pick up the slab on which Sergei’s a DC 15 Intelligence check allows a PC to notice that the coffin rests to throw it. statue in the center alcove is different from the others. It Rock Catching (Ex) A stone giant gains a +4 racial bonus on appears cruder, less regal, and its royal accoutrements seem its Reflex save when attempting to catch a thrown rock. to fit poorly. It holds its rod of rulership more like a club than an instrument of authority, for example. That’s because this statue is really a stone giant, held in stasis and awaiting Strahd’s command to step out of the alcove and attack. It moves first to PCs closest to the marble slab, and it attacks until it is killed. If it is not killed and the encounter ends, it returns to its alcove and renters stasis. After 24 hours, it is again ready for Strahd’s command, at full health and ready to attack.
name: Statues

description: The 5 foot-diameter tunnel is es- sentially vertical, but is so roughly burrowed through the stone that a DC 10 Climb check is sufficient to ascend or descend the tunnel. The tunnel drops 30 feet into a complex of 3-foot-diameter tunnels that lead every which way and are filled with a bustle of giant worker ants (100+) and, somewhere, the queen ant. If a determined PC were to map out all the tunnels over the T M D ACTICAL AP ETAILS course of a couple of long days, he or she would eventually dis- Details on the tactical map are described below. cover an entrance to the outside world, some 500 feet north of
name: Tunnel in Floor
